title: Yabco Focus Company Limited creates employment in Upper East
text:
20 October 2015 11:00 CET Yabco Focus Company Limited creates employment in Upper East By GNA 
Bolgatanga, Oct 19, GNA - The Yabco Focus Company Limited in the Upper East Region, which uses indigenous economic trees to produce fruit juice, has employed a number of youth in the area. 
The Company is the first in the region to process, preserve and package fruits juices made from the fruits of indigenous economic tree such as the Baobab, Tamarind and mango for the local market in the Region and parts of northern Ghana, Ashanti and Greater Accra regions. 
Apart from the fruit juices, the Company has established sachet water production and car washing facilities in the Bolgatanga Municipality to give employment to the youth. 
The Chief Executive Officer of the Company, Mr Baba Yabdow, told the GNA in an interview in Bolgatanga on Saturday that the Company had employed about 40 young people. 
He said apart from the direct employment his company had created in the region, it has also engaged women groups in the rural areas to harvest the boabab, Tamarind and mango fruits. 
Mr Yabdow stated that the Northern Ecological Zones had indigenous economic trees that could be harnessed to reduce poverty and help bridge the gap between the northern and southern sector. 
He mentioned for instance that the Boabab tree, which is often referred to as the tree of life, wisdom, prosperity and productivity, had a lifespan of about 3,000 to 5,000 years and could be found all over the Northern Ecological zones. 
He said a research conducted by his outfit on the medicinal values of the Boabab, Tamarind and mango fruits revealed that they had a lot of health benefits including the reduction of blood sugar level, boost of the immune system, aid in stress management, body fitness, weight management, aid in the digestion lowering of cholesterol and improving the eye sight. 
'The economic values of the boabab fruit cannot be overemphasized as it is very rich in vitamin C. It contains six times more vitamin than the orange, six times richer in potassium than banana, and twice as rich in calcium than milk. 
Most of the households in the communities especially the rural settings of the northern ecological zones particularly Upper East Region use the leaves of the trees for the preparation of soup, which is very nutritious, the CEO said. 
The company as part of its corporate social responsibility had also sunk boreholes for some communities including Kpale in the Nabdam District and Yikine in the Bolgatanga Municipality. 
He commended the Savannah Accelerated Development Authority (SADA) and Dr Ken Kwame Kwaku, a philanthropist for supporting the company to thrive, 
He appealed to SADA and other development partners for more support to expand the company to compliment government's efforts at creating more jobs for the youth. 
GNA
